stem: An 18-year-old with Type 1 Diabetes is admitted with thirst, polyuria, and confusion. Labs: Glucose 540 mg/dL, pH 7.22, HCO3 12, Ketones positive in urine. Complete the bowtie to plan the clinical management.

rationale.correct: This is a classic DKA presentation (Age < 30, Type 1, Ketoacidosis). Treatment priority is hydration (0.9% NS) and intravenous insulin. Monitoring glucose and electrolytes (especially K+) is critical during recovery.
rationale.incorrect: Subcutaneous insulin is not for crisis management. Dextrose is added only after glucose drops below 250 mg/dL, not immediately. A1c is for long-term monitoring, not acute crisis.
clinicalPearls: Insulin moves potassium into the cells; always check K+ before and during insulin drip.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Even if labs show 'normal' K+, total body K+ is low in DKA. It will drop further with insulin.

Monitoring glucose and electrolytes (especially K+) is critical during recovery. Insulin moves potassium into the cells; always check K+ before and during insulin drip.

reviewUnits.heading: Priority Interventions for Diabetic Ketoacidosis
reviewUnits.body: The priority nursing interventions are: Initiate IV 0.9% National Saline bolus; Start Regular Insulin infusion (0.1 units/kg/hr). Monitor: Blood Glucose levels hourly; Serum Potassium and Anion Gap. Subcutaneous insulin is not for crisis management. Dextrose is added only after glucose drops below 250 mg/dL, not immediately. A1c is for long-term monitoring, not acute crisis.
